A set is a collection of distinct objects considered as an entity.
System of Generators of an Ideal

Let $\mathfrak{a}$ be an ideal of a ring $R$. A family $\left(a_{i}\right)_{i \in I}$ of elements in $\mathfrak{a}$ is called a system of generators of $\mathfrak{a}$ if $\mathfrak{a}=\sum_{i \in I} R a_{i}$, i.e., if $\mathfrak{a}$ coincides with the ideal generated by the family $\left(a_{i}\right)_{i \in I}$.
Does the concept of a/an Set need to be defined for a definition of a/an System of Generators of an Ideal to make sense? (True if the first concept is needed and False if is not.)

Explanation: To determine if the concept of a set is necessary for the definition of a system of generators of an ideal, we need to analyze the components of the latter definition. The definition of a system of generators of an ideal involves a family \((a_i)_{i \in I}\) of elements in an ideal \(\mathfrak{a}\) of a ring \(R\). This family is indexed by some index set \(I\), which is implicitly a set. The family \((a_i)_{i \in I}\) itself can be thought of as a function from the set \(I\) to the elements of the ideal \(\mathfrak{a}\). The definition also involves the concept of the sum of ideals generated by each element of the family, which is another set-theoretic operation (union of sets of elements). Thus, the concept of a set underlies both the indexing of the family and the operations performed on its elements. Without the concept of a set, the notion of an indexed family of elements and the operation of forming sums of ideals (which are sets of elements) would not be well-defined.
